snippet: After fleeing violence in their Central American homelands, thousands of minors are crowding courtrooms in New York City and Long Island that are ill equipped to handle the volume.
abstract: Thousands of Central American children who fled crime-ridden countries in 2014 for United States are overwhelming legal system, by sheer volume, as they seek relief from deportation; while a small percent have been granted asylum, 69 percent of children on priority immigration court dockets across nation still have cases pending; New York City offers some legal advantages for child immigrants, with city-backed coalition of nonprofit agencies and pro bono lawyers offering free legal assistance.

byline.contributor: David Gonzalez and Isvett Verde contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: After fleeing violence in their Central American homelands, thousands of minors are crowding courtrooms in New York City and Long Island that are ill equipped to handle the volume.

headline.main: Immigration Crisis Shifts From Border to Courts
